data.title: Index SC
data.text:
* Margaret, who never set foot in Scotland, d. at age 7 and the legitimate issue of William I became extinct. A trial was held, supervised by King Edward I of England, and 14 candidates for the throne presented themselves:

John Balliol, descendant of Henry Huntingdon

Robert de Brus, descendant of Henry Huntingdon

Edward I of England, descendant of King Malcolm III

William de Ros, descendant of King William I's natural daughter

Eric II of Norway, Queen Margaret's father

Floris V of Holland, descendant of Henry Huntingdon

Patrick Dunbar, descendant of King William I's natural daughter; also closest agnate of House of Dunkeld

Patrick Galithly, descendant of William I's natural son

Roger de Mandeville, descendant of William I's natural daughter

Nicholas de Soules, descendant of Duncan I

John Hastings, descendant of Henry Huntingdon

William de Vesci, descendant of King William I's natural daughter

John Comyn, descendant of King Donald III

Robert de Pinkeney, descendant of Henry Huntingdon

Of these claims, only those of Baliol and Brus were really serious. King Edward I used the crisis to increase his power in Scotland, sided with the Baliol faction, and eventually claimed the throne for himself. King John abdicated in 1296 and Edward I waged war with William Wallace for control of Scotland.

We do not show all the Regents during this troubled period. (Although English domination persisted until the 1314 Battle of Bannockburn, and their claim was not formally renounced until 1328, we do not show Edward's heirs in this list.)
